content: Can someone explain what happened to #95140? I thought it was a fine issue cleaning up code style inconsistencies and inefficient string building. Is there some guideline on not improving code to keep git blame clean?
Not a general policy or guideline, just someone making a judgment call.
In general, large code cleanups have a weird risk-reward tradeoff.

If everything goes well, they have no functional change, and they might make the code more maintainable in the future.
But they also have the potential to introduce issues, require careful review as a result, and they do make git blame much less useful.
I'm a big fan of cleaning up code, but these tradeoffs come up on a PR-by-PR basis.
